channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Leeds child heart ops 'had to stop'
item.description: The medical director of the NHS defends the suspension of child heart surgery at Leeds General Infirmary while a safety review is carried out.

item.title: Actor Richard Griffiths dies aged 65
item.description: Actor Richard Griffiths, star of the Harry Potter movies and Withnail and I, dies after complications following heart surgery at the age of 65.

item.title: Obituary: Richard Griffiths
item.description: Griffiths, one of Britain's most celebrated character actors has died of complications after having heart surgery, aged 65.

item.title: Russia warns of North Korea 'spiral'
item.description: Russia warns of tensions in North Korea slipping out of control, after Pyongyang announces it is "time to settle accounts" with the US and puts missile units on stand-by,

item.title: Mandela making 'steady progress'
item.description: Nelson Mandela is making "steady progress" after a second day in hospital for treatment of a lung infection, South African President Jacob Zuma says.

item.title: Tanzania collapse 'traps dozens'
item.description: At least three people are killed and dozens more trapped after a multi-storey building collapses in the main Tanzanian city, Dar es Salaam, rescuers say.

item.title: Teachers press on with strike plan
item.description: Teachers’ union leaders say they will not back down in their pay dispute, despite the government ruling out any change to their pay plan.

item.title: Bosnia jails Serb for war crimes
item.description: A court in Bosnia-Hercegovina sentences a Montenegrin Serb to 45 years in prison for murder, rape and torture during the 1992-95 conflict.

item.title: Mother held after girl left in pram
item.description: A mother is arrested on suspicion of child neglect after her two-year-old daughter was found abandoned in a pram in Cumbria.

item.title: Obama: 'Work still to be done in NI'
item.description: The American President Barack Obama has said there is urgent work still to be done in the Peace Process in Northern Ireland.

item.title: Cyprus 'will not leave the euro'
item.description: Cyprus President Nicos Anastasiades says the island has no intention of leaving the euro, despite the tough conditions imposed by its bailout.

item.title: Two men die during police car chase
item.description: Two men die when the car they were travelling in crashes during a police chase in north London.

item.title: Benefits reform trial scaled back
item.description: The government is to scale back some of its plans to test a radical new reform to the welfare system.

item.title: Olympic Park opens up for tours
item.description: The London Olympic Park is reopened to visitors with 20,000 tickets sold in advance.

item.title: Scott last letter published in full
item.description: One of Captain Scott's final letters written from the south pole is made public to mark 101 years since his final diary entry on 29 March 1912.

item.title: Why I had to leave football - Rogers
item.description: Former Leeds winger Robbie Rogers says playing pro football after declaring your homosexuality is "impossible".

item.title: Wigan 28-16 St Helens
item.description: Wigan Warriors see off a second-half revival from St Helens to claim a hard-fought victory over their local rivals.

item.title: England fan claims are 'hearsay'
item.description: England fans criticise anti-racism group Fare for reporting chanting in San Marino on the basis of "hearsay".

item.title: Bolt close to making London return
item.description: Usain Bolt's agent says "positive negotiations" have taken place about the sprinter competing at the London 2012 Anniversary Games.

item.title: Lester landmark for female jockeys
item.description: Lucy Alexander and Amy Ryan win Lesters for 2012 - the first time two individual female jockeys have won the awards.

item.title: Camera chain Jessops re-launches
item.description: Camera chain Jessops has re-opened two of its stores just a couple of months after going into administration in January with the closure of 187 branches

item.title: Post Office staff to go on strike
item.description: Thousands of staff at Post Office Crown offices are due to go on strike in a row over jobs, pay and branch closures.

item.title: Mitchell to sue Sun over 'plebgate'
item.description: Former cabinet minister Andrew Mitchell is suing the Sun over claims he swore and called police officers plebs in a row in Downing Street, his lawyer says.

item.title: Andrew Parker named new MI5 chief
item.description: The new director general of the domestic security service, known as MI5, is to be current deputy Andrew Parker.

item.title: Cancer survivors deserve 'care plan'
item.description: All cancer patients should receive a 'recovery package' at the end of their treatment offering ongoing support, the government has announced.

item.title: Heart patients 'helped by vest'
item.description: Doctors in London have been using special vests to help diagnose abnormal heart rhythms, in the first UK test of its kind.

item.title: University protesters to be evicted
item.description: The High Court rules that protesters should be evicted from part of the University of Sussex.

item.title: GCSE changes 'work against girls'
item.description: Changes to GCSE examinations in England could be to the disadvantage of girls and see their results fall, teachers warn.

item.title: Amazon buys book recommendation site
item.description: Online retailer Amazon says it will buy a book discovery and recommendation website Goodreads, which has 16 million members.

item.title: Blackberry reports 1m Z10 sales
item.description: Mobile phone maker Blackberry says it sold one million of its new Z10 smartphones, but has lost three million users.

item.title: Met Office advice was 'not helpful'
item.description: The Met Office has admitted issuing "unhelpful" advice to government during last year's remarkable switch in weather patterns.

item.title: Spacecraft shortens trip to ISS
item.description: A Soyuz space capsule docks at the International Space Station (ISS) after a journey of under six hours - much shorter than the normal two-day flight.

item.title: Pink Floyd album inspires radio play
item.description: The 40th anniversary of Pink Floyd's 1973 Dark Side of the Moon album is to marked on BBC Radio 2 by an hour-long audio drama by Sir Tom Stoppard.

item.title: Louvre is most visited venue of 2012
item.description: The Louvre in Paris tops the list of the most visited art museums of 2012, according to the Art Newspaper.

item.title: The rise of online STI dating
item.description: There's a boom in dating websites for people with incurable sexually transmitted infections. Is this the answer for those nervous of telling new partners?

item.title: Pleasures and perils of open-plan offices
item.description: They can be noisy and distracting or deathly quiet environments - so why do so many of us continue to work in open-plan offices?

item.title: Fostering benefit leaflet criticised
item.description: A London council is criticised by Nick Clegg for sending out leaflets suggesting people foster a child to avoid losing benefits if they have empty bedrooms.

item.title: Avalanche warning for fell walkers
item.description: Fell walkers in Cumbria are warned to prepare for avalanche conditions over the Easter weekend.

item.title: Horsemeat found in primary schools
item.description: A batch of frozen mince supplied to six schools in Edinburgh contained between 1% and 5% horsemeat, the city's council confirms.

item.title: Power 'fully restored' after cuts
item.description: Every property left without electricity after last Friday's snow storm has now had its supply restored, according to energy firm SSE.

item.title: Air support goes in relief effort
item.description: All air support has now been withdrawn from the relief operation to animals stranded in the snow in Northern Ireland.

item.title: City of Culture director resigns
item.description: Dermot McLaughlin has resigned from his role as Derry City Council's City of Culture project director.

item.title: School dinners clear of horsemeat
item.description: No horsemeat or pig DNA is found in food samples taken from schools and care homes in Cardiff after tests were ordered by the city council.

item.title: Mum's 'nightmare' since crash death
item.description: The mother of a young man who died when his car crashed into a wall backs a police campaign to prevent drug and drink driving.

item.title: New UN force to target Congo rebels
item.description: A special combat force is approved by the United Nations for the first time, to be sent to battle rebel groups in the eastern DR Congo.

item.title: France sets Mali troop timetable
item.description: France aims to reduce the number of its troops fighting Islamist militants in Mali to 1,000 by the end of the year, President Francois Hollande says.

item.title: Musharraf bail extended amid chaos
item.description: A court in Pakistan extends bail for former President Pervez Musharraf, amid chaotic scenes in which a shoe is thrown at him.

item.title: S Lanka crowd attacks Muslim store
item.description: Several people are injured in the Sri Lankan capital, Colombo, as Buddhist monks lead hundreds of people in an assault on a Muslim-owned clothing warehouse.

item.title: Berlusconi rejects technocrat deal
item.description: Italian centre-right leader Silvio Berlusconi opposes the idea of a new technocratic government for Italy like that led by Mario Monti.

item.title: Latvia ice floe strands beachgoers
item.description: A rescue operation is launched after two ice floes drift off the Latvian coast, leaving 220 beachgoers trapped at sea in the Gulf of Riga.

item.title: Students and police clash in Chile
item.description: Thousands of Chilean students clash with police on the streets of the capital, Santiago, during a protest calling for education reforms.

item.title: Wave blamed for Amazon port accident
item.description: A mining company in Brazil says a giant wave is to blame for the collapse and sinking of a floating port on the Amazon river, in the state of Amapa.

item.title: Car bombs hit Iraqi worshippers
item.description: A series of car bomb attacks in Baghdad and Kirkuk have targeted Shia mosques during Friday prayers, killing at least 18 people.

item.title: US ex-soldier 'fought in Syria'
item.description: An American ex-soldier is charged with using a weapon outside the US as he fought against Syrian government forces, prosecutors say.

item.title: Obama promotes infrastructure plan
item.description: US President Barack Obama appeals for private funds for infrastructure projects, in a bid to create jobs without adding to the budget deficit.

item.title: Newtown gunman 'had weapons arsenal'
item.description: Ammunition, guns and swords were among items found at the home of the gunman who killed 27 people last December in Connecticut, court papers show.

item.title: Mozambique: Life in pictures
item.description: Ariadne Van Zandbergen explores this changing country

item.title: Your pictures: On the edge
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme On the edge

item.title: Day in pictures: 27 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 27 March

item.title: In pictures: Losing Ground
item.description: Communities in Cambodia fight for their right to land

item.title: Day in pictures: 26 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 26 March

item.title: In pictures: Shifting Perspectives
item.description: Representation of people with Down’s syndrome

item.title: Day in pictures: 25 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 25 March

item.title: In Pictures: Rowena Cade's theatre
item.description: The Minack Theatre prepares for its new season

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: The health secretary has set out the government's response to the Stafford Hospital inquiry.

item.title: VIDEO: Spacecraft shortens trip to ISS
item.description: A Soyuz space capsule has docked at the International Space Station (ISS) after a journey of less than six hours.

item.title: VIDEO: Robot ants mimic insect behaviour
item.description: Tiny robotic ants created by scientists in the US are able to navigate through a network by following one another's trail, footage reveals.

item.title: VIDEO: View the vest helping heart patients
item.description: Doctors have praised a new vest which enables them to treat patients more successfully by detecting heart defects.

item.title: VIDEO: Fish market gets 'seal' of approval
item.description: More than 150 species of fish and shellfish from all over the world are sold at Billingsgate Market in London but a seal, nicknamed Sammy by porters, prefers to be fed salmon.

item.title: AUDIO: Actor Griffiths on playing Uncle Monty
item.description: Actor Richard Griffiths, who starred in the Harry Potter movies and Withnail and I, has died at the age of 65 after complications following heart surgery.

item.title: VIDEO: The Bible hooks US TV audiences
item.description: Millions of Americans are expected to tune in to The History Channel on Sunday for the culmination of one of the year's surprise cable TV hits: a five part dramatisation of The Bible.

item.title: AUDIO: Thought for the Day: Justin Welby
item.description: Thought for the Day from the Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby.

item.title: VIDEO: Botched burglary caught on camera
item.description: Police in California have released surveillance video footage of a botched burglary in a bid to track down the suspect.

item.title: Viewpoints: Stopping dangerous dogs
item.description: What should be done about dangerous dogs?

item.title: The rise of chocolate purism
item.description: Is 100% cocoa chocolate really better than the rest?

item.title: Nepal seeks Asian tourism boost
item.description: Nepal seeks to attract more tourists from Asian nations

item.title: Quiz of the week's news
item.description: Which Glastonbury act also played at Woodstock?

item.title: Stockholm museum thanks Abba for the music
item.description: The Swedes hoping band museum will be tourist magnet

item.title: 100 years of carmaking in Oxford
item.description: Oxford's 100 years of carmaking in pictures

item.title: VIDEO: Mexico's urban youth culture explosion
item.description: Mexico's street culture explosion challenges status quo

item.title: In pictures: Syria refugee keepsakes
item.description: The simple treasures people fleeing Syria have held close

item.title: Cyprus: We apologise for any inconvenience...
item.description: How will Cypriot banks explain this one in online banking speak?

item.title: Cyprus: Clouds of uncertainty over island
item.description: Paul Mason watches the banks reopen in Cyprus

item.title: Miliband joins list of 'nearly men'
item.description: Why didn't David Miliband quite make it to the top?
